speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: SCENE II. The Forum.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Enter BRUTUS and CASSIUS, and a throng of Citizens

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: We will be satisfied; let us be satisfied.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Then follow me, and give me audience, friends.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Cassius, go you into the other street,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And part the numbers.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Those that will hear me speak, let 'em stay here;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Those that will follow Cassius, go with him;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And public reasons shall be rendered

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Of Caesar's death.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: I will hear Brutus speak.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: I will hear Cassius; and compare their reasons,

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: When severally we hear them rendered.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Exit CASSIUS, with some of the Citizens. BRUTUS goes into the pulpit

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: The noble Brutus is ascended: silence!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Be patient till the last.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Romans, countrymen, and lovers! hear me for my

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: cause, and be silent, that you may hear: believe me

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: for mine honour, and have respect to mine honour, that

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: you may believe: censure me in your wisdom, and

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: awake your senses, that you may the better judge.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If there be any in this assembly, any dear friend of

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Caesar's, to him I say, that Brutus' love to Caesar

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: was no less than his. If then that friend demand

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: why Brutus rose against Caesar, this is my answer:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: --Not that I loved Caesar less, but that I loved

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Rome more. Had you rather Caesar were living and

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: die all slaves, than that Caesar were dead, to live

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: all free men? As Caesar loved me, I weep for him;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: as he was fortunate, I rejoice at it; as he was

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: valiant, I honour him: but, as he was ambitious, I

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: slew him. There is tears for his love; joy for his

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: fortune; honour for his valour; and death for his

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: ambition. Who is here so base that would be a

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: bondman? If any, speak; for him have I offended.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Who is here so rude that would not be a Roman? If

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: any, speak; for him have I offended. Who is here so

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: vile that will not love his country? If any, speak;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: for him have I offended. I pause for a reply.

speaker: All
text_entry: None, Brutus, none.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Then none have I offended. I have done no more to

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Caesar than you shall do to Brutus. The question of

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: his death is enrolled in the Capitol; his glory not

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: extenuated, wherein he was worthy, nor his offences

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: enforced, for which he suffered death.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enter ANTONY and others, with CAESAR's body

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony: who,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: though he had no hand in his death, shall receive

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: the benefit of his dying, a place in the

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: commonwealth; as which of you shall not? With this

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I depart,--that, as I slew my best lover for the

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: good of Rome, I have the same dagger for myself,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: when it shall please my country to need my death.

speaker: All
text_entry: Live, Brutus! live, live!

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Bring him with triumph home unto his house.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Give him a statue with his ancestors.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Let him be Caesar.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Caesar's better parts

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Shall be crown'd in Brutus.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: We'll bring him to his house

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: With shouts and clamours.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: My countrymen,--

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Peace, silence! Brutus speaks.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Peace, ho!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Good countrymen, let me depart alone,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And, for my sake, stay here with Antony:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Do grace to Caesar's corpse, and grace his speech

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Tending to Caesar's glories; which Mark Antony,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By our permission, is allow'd to make.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I do entreat you, not a man depart,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Save I alone, till Antony have spoke.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Stay, ho! and let us hear Mark Antony.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Let him go up into the public chair;

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: We'll hear him. Noble Antony, go up.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: For Brutus' sake, I am beholding to you.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Goes into the pulpit

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: What does he say of Brutus?

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: He says, for Brutus' sake,

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: He finds himself beholding to us all.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: 'Twere best he speak no harm of Brutus here.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: This Caesar was a tyrant.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Nay, that's certain:

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: We are blest that Rome is rid of him.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Peace! let us hear what Antony can say.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: You gentle Romans,--

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: Peace, ho! let us hear him.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I come to bury Caesar, not to praise him.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: The evil that men do lives after them;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: The good is oft interred with their bones;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: So let it be with Caesar. The noble Brutus

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Hath told you Caesar was ambitious:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: If it were so, it was a grievous fault,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And grievously hath Caesar answer'd it.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Here, under leave of Brutus and the rest--

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: For Brutus is an honourable man;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: So are they all, all honourable men--

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Come I to speak in Caesar's funeral.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: He was my friend, faithful and just to me:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: But Brutus says he was ambitious;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And Brutus is an honourable man.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: He hath brought many captives home to Rome

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Whose ransoms did the general coffers fill:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Did this in Caesar seem ambitious?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: When that the poor have cried, Caesar hath wept:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Ambition should be made of sterner stuff:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Yet Brutus says he was ambitious;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And Brutus is an honourable man.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: You all did see that on the Lupercal

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I thrice presented him a kingly crown,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Which he did thrice refuse: was this ambition?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Yet Brutus says he was ambitious;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And, sure, he is an honourable man.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I speak not to disprove what Brutus spoke,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: But here I am to speak what I do know.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: You all did love him once, not without cause:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: What cause withholds you then, to mourn for him?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: O judgment! thou art fled to brutish beasts,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And men have lost their reason. Bear with me;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: My heart is in the coffin there with Caesar,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And I must pause till it come back to me.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Methinks there is much reason in his sayings.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: If thou consider rightly of the matter,

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Caesar has had great wrong.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Has he, masters?

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: I fear there will a worse come in his place.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Mark'd ye his words? He would not take the crown;

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Therefore 'tis certain he was not ambitious.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: If it be found so, some will dear abide it.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Poor soul! his eyes are red as fire with weeping.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: There's not a nobler man in Rome than Antony.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Now mark him, he begins again to speak.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: But yesterday the word of Caesar might

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Have stood against the world; now lies he there.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And none so poor to do him reverence.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: O masters, if I were disposed to stir

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I should do Brutus wrong, and Cassius wrong,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Who, you all know, are honourable men:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I will not do them wrong; I rather choose

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To wrong the dead, to wrong myself and you,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Than I will wrong such honourable men.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: But here's a parchment with the seal of Caesar;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I found it in his closet, 'tis his will:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Let but the commons hear this testament--

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Which, pardon me, I do not mean to read--

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And they would go and kiss dead Caesar's wounds

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And dip their napkins in his sacred blood,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Yea, beg a hair of him for memory,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And, dying, mention it within their wills,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Bequeathing it as a rich legacy

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Unto their issue.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: We'll hear the will: read it, Mark Antony.

speaker: All
text_entry: The will, the will! we will hear Caesar's will.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Have patience, gentle friends, I must not read it;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: It is not meet you know how Caesar loved you.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: You are not wood, you are not stones, but men;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And, being men, bearing the will of Caesar,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: It will inflame you, it will make you mad:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: 'Tis good you know not that you are his heirs;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: For, if you should, O, what would come of it!

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Read the will; we'll hear it, Antony;

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: You shall read us the will, Caesar's will.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Will you be patient? will you stay awhile?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I have o'ershot myself to tell you of it:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I fear I wrong the honourable men

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Whose daggers have stabb'd Caesar; I do fear it.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: They were traitors: honourable men!

speaker: All
text_entry: The will! the testament!

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: They were villains, murderers: the will! read the will.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: You will compel me, then, to read the will?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Then make a ring about the corpse of Caesar,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And let me show you him that made the will.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Shall I descend? and will you give me leave?

speaker: Several Citizens
text_entry: Come down.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Descend.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: You shall have leave.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: ANTONY comes down

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: A ring; stand round.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Stand from the hearse, stand from the body.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Room for Antony, most noble Antony.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Nay, press not so upon me; stand far off.

speaker: Several Citizens
text_entry: Stand back; room; bear back.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: If you have tears, prepare to shed them now.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: You all do know this mantle: I remember

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: The first time ever Caesar put it on;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: 'Twas on a summer's evening, in his tent,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That day he overcame the Nervii:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Look, in this place ran Cassius' dagger through:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: See what a rent the envious Casca made:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Through this the well-beloved Brutus stabb'd;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And as he pluck'd his cursed steel away,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Mark how the blood of Caesar follow'd it,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: As rushing out of doors, to be resolved

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: If Brutus so unkindly knock'd, or no;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar's angel:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Judge, O you gods, how dearly Caesar loved him!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: This was the most unkindest cut of all;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: For when the noble Caesar saw him stab,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Ingratitude, more strong than traitors' arms,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Quite vanquish'd him: then burst his mighty heart;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And, in his mantle muffling up his face,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Even at the base of Pompey's statua,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Which all the while ran blood, great Caesar fell.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: O, what a fall was there, my countrymen!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Then I, and you, and all of us fell down,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Whilst bloody treason flourish'd over us.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: O, now you weep; and, I perceive, you feel

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: The dint of pity: these are gracious drops.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Kind souls, what, weep you when you but behold

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Our Caesar's vesture wounded? Look you here,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Here is himself, marr'd, as you see, with traitors.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: O piteous spectacle!

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: O noble Caesar!

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: O woful day!

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: O traitors, villains!

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: O most bloody sight!

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: We will be revenged.

speaker: All
text_entry: Revenge! About! Seek! Burn! Fire! Kill! Slay!

speaker: All
text_entry: Let not a traitor live!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Stay, countrymen.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Peace there! hear the noble Antony.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: We'll hear him, we'll follow him, we'll die with him.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Good friends, sweet friends, let me not stir you up

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To such a sudden flood of mutiny.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: They that have done this deed are honourable:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: What private griefs they have, alas, I know not,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That made them do it: they are wise and honourable,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And will, no doubt, with reasons answer you.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I come not, friends, to steal away your hearts:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I am no orator, as Brutus is;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: But, as you know me all, a plain blunt man,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That love my friend; and that they know full well

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That gave me public leave to speak of him:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: For I have neither wit, nor words, nor worth,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Action, nor utterance, nor the power of speech,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To stir men's blood: I only speak right on;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I tell you that which you yourselves do know;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Show you sweet Caesar's wounds, poor poor dumb mouths,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And bid them speak for me: but were I Brutus,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And Brutus Antony, there were an Antony

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Would ruffle up your spirits and put a tongue

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: In every wound of Caesar that should move

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: The stones of Rome to rise and mutiny.

speaker: All
text_entry: We'll mutiny.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: We'll burn the house of Brutus.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Away, then! come, seek the conspirators.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Yet hear me, countrymen; yet hear me speak.

speaker: All
text_entry: Peace, ho! Hear Antony. Most noble Antony!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Why, friends, you go to do you know not what:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Wherein hath Caesar thus deserved your loves?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Alas, you know not: I must tell you then:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: You have forgot the will I told you of.

speaker: All
text_entry: Most true. The will! Let's stay and hear the will.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Here is the will, and under Caesar's seal.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To every Roman citizen he gives,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To every several man, seventy-five drachmas.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Most noble Caesar! We'll revenge his death.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: O royal Caesar!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Hear me with patience.

speaker: All
text_entry: Peace, ho!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Moreover, he hath left you all his walks,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: His private arbours and new-planted orchards,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: On this side Tiber; he hath left them you,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And to your heirs for ever, common pleasures,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To walk abroad, and recreate yourselves.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Here was a Caesar! when comes such another?

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Never, never. Come, away, away!

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: We'll burn his body in the holy place,

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: And with the brands fire the traitors' houses.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Take up the body.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Go fetch fire.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Pluck down benches.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Pluck down forms, windows, any thing.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Exeunt Citizens with the body

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Now let it work. Mischief, thou art afoot,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Take thou what course thou wilt!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: How now, fellow!

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Sir, Octavius is already come to Rome.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Where is he?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: He and Lepidus are at Caesar's house.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And thither will I straight to visit him:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: He comes upon a wish. Fortune is merry,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And in this mood will give us any thing.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: I heard him say, Brutus and Cassius

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Are rid like madmen through the gates of Rome.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Belike they had some notice of the people,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: How I had moved them. Bring me to Octavius.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Exeunt
